ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned to cope with and analyse texts from one of the most complicated literary traditions I have ever encountered, through the use of close reading, attention to para-text, and of course a great arsenal of theoretical tool. Not many literature students are aware of the richness of Maghrebi literature, and prior to the arrival of Prof. Jarvis to Yale, there was no true expert to instruct this field; I believe her presence will soon create a community of students and scholars of the French North African corpus, a field crucial for any group trying to think about world literature and all that it entails.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course was excellent, it had a very precise balance between theory and literature, between "lecture" parts and class discussions and between individual and communal work. No distinct weaknesses!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this class to anyone who is interested in the colonial and postcolonial Middle East and theories of violence and subjugation. It was also extremely compelling in regards to questions of language.
